Much is at stake as the war continues.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Fbusiness%20functions%2Fstrategy%20and%20corporate%20finance%2Four%20insights%2Fthe%20rising%20toll%20of%20the%20war%20in%20ukraine%2Fthe-rising-toll-of-the-war-in-ukraine-vf.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="the-rising-toll-of-the-war-in-ukraine-vf" data-layer-report-name="the-rising-toll-of-the-war-in-ukraine-vf>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (6 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>In this episode</strong> of <em><a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast">The McKinsey Podcast</a></em>, Sven Smit, senior partner and chair of the McKinsey Global Institute, talks with Lucia Rahilly, global editorial director, about some of the potential effects of ongoing war and uncertainty in Ukraine. This conversation was recorded on March 21, 2022. An edited transcript follows.</p>
<p><em>The McKinsey Podcast</em> is cohosted by Roberta Fusaro and Lucia Rahilly.</p>
<!-- -->
<h2>A humanand humanitariancrisis </h2>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly:</strong> I recognize this is a chaotic time for you, given the brutal effects of the war in Ukraine and ongoing shock and uncertainty, both in the European region and worldwide. Were very grateful you were able to make the time to talk with us today.</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit:</strong> Its indeed a complex time. I live in Europe, and this is so close that you cant get it out of your heart. My mother is 80. She lived in Eastern Germany and fled from government oppression in the 60s. She didnt think she would live to see this again. And now its happening on our territory while were watching. This is a true atrocity and a humanitarian pain thats unimaginable.</p>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>The war clearly affects all of us, but it must be particularly acutely felt in Europe, even outside the conflict zone. Its the largest war in Europe in nearly eight decades. So I would imagine youre hearing similar things from the leaders you talk to day-to-day.</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit:</strong> Yes. The pandemic is a virus. We can fight it with masks and vaccines. But in Ukraine, were fighting human against humanand thats just so different.</p>

<h2>Lives and livelihoods, lost and disrupted</h2>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>This war is obviously causing massive disruption on a range of fronts. We cant talk today about all of them, but lets touch on at least a few. The foremost disruption, as you alluded to, is the horrific and rising toll on lives. What have we learned so far about the scale of this humanitarian tragedyand about who is likely to bear the brunt of much of this suffering?	</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>At the moment, north of a few million people are moving out of Ukraine as refugees. That number could grow much bigger if the hostilities protract for the remainder of the year. Some people estimate it might then go north of ten million, 15 million. But there are different segmentsthe lives lost in the direct war, the displacement of refugees, and the displacement within Ukraine.</p>
<p>The energy and food crises are also pinching at the lives and livelihoods of people across the world. Among some less-well-off populations in Western Europe or the United States, energy and food make up 1030 percent of what they spend. The price doubles, triplesall of a sudden, these people cant do anything else but pay for food and energy. So you see some people already adjusting their behavior, eating less. And some of them just cant pay.</p>
<p>Then you multiply that in a low-income countryone that maybe had an aspiring population, ready to go up the next step. Now these people get pinched by this increased price of food, increased price of energy, maybe even decreased access to food and energy. And you can easily imagine that more lives and livelihoods will be lost and disrupted outside the immediate conflict. We should not miss that. In the pandemic, there was a little bit of an under-told story: richer countries were really not paying enough attention to the pain of this economic disruption in lower-income countries.</p>
<h2>Rising prices, rising risk</h2>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>Food prices spiked even prior to the war, given supply chain issues and rising energy prices during the pandemic. In the US, we saw grocery prices shoot up at the highest rate in something like 40 years. Do you see increased food insecurity in Europeand potentially also an increase in world hungeras a big risk as a result of this war?</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>We havent yet seen shipments of oil, gas, and food stopping at a massive scale. There hasnt been a major harvest disrupted in the northern territory, which could happen if this goes through the summer. We also havent yet seen some form of sanction or countersanction or hostility saying, Lets not ship the oil. But if that changes, either by physical disruption or by intent, we may see problems with access.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>At the moment, prices are rising in anticipation of potential shortages. And what will happen is high-income countries will buytheyll be able to pay. And lower-income countries will have access problemsor at minimum, even greater affordability problems.</p>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>In some lower-income countries, there is also a history of food shortages and rising food costs contributing to social unrest and uprising. </p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>Thats not just a risk in low-income countries. The yellow-vest movement reacted to an increase in diesel prices. Only a small increase in these itemswhich you need to buy to stay warm, to drive to your job, to earn an incomeis very disruptive. It means you have to stop buying other stuff. And thats where the pain comes. Of course, for some, that means not going on holidaynot the worst thing in life. But for others, it means cutting back on essentials because their spend gets crowded out by these enormous price rises.</p>
<p>Were all experiencing just how sensitive a doubling of the price in oil or doubling in the price of food is to the spending patterns of the lower-income parts of the population. Its very easy for higher-income people to say, You know, this is part of the fight, but it really pinches other segments of the population.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Prices are rising in anticipation of potential shortages. And what will happen is high-income countries will buytheyll be able to pay. And lower-income countries will have access problems.</p></blockquote></div>
<h2>What about net zero?</h2>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>Energy is obviously a huge disruption, given the role of Russian oil and gas not just in Europe but worldwide. I saw a quote a couple of days ago from the International Energy Agency warning that we could be headed into what they called the biggest supply crisis in decades. Sven, youve been so heavily involved in our energy research, including our recent report on the <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-net-zero-transition-what-it-would-cost-what-it-could-bring">net-zero transition</a>. Anything more to say about energy access, at least in the near to medium term?</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>The first point is the energy is still flowing. But it could stop flowing. So we need to do much more radical things. </p>
<p>Currently, the energy policy of major countries is rotating: Lets build more wind. Lets build more solar. Lets build more nuclear. Its almost like saying, Lets try everything and find out what protects us the fastest. What that does to net zero, what that does to the <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/solving-the-net-zero-equation-nine-requirements-for-a-more-orderly-transition">net-zero equation</a>, I think we will only learn over time. Because the reality is that some countries might start reoperating coal plants as the fastest way to become somewhat less dependent. And other countries might actually <a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/capturing-the-wind-renewable-energy-opportunities-in-vietnam">finalize the wind farms</a> that are already there.</p>
<p>For now, people are going to go all out. And then, at some point, we will resettle into a new equilibrium, which could go either way. For physical supply chains of energy that are now at stake, oil travels a little bit more on boats and can therefore be flexibly reallocated, while gas needs to be liquefied and then re-gassed. And the capacity for liquefication (SIC) and re-gassing is actually short. As a result, if we were to have a gas shortage, rebuilding might take a lot of timemuch more time than we ever want.</p>
<h2>Supply chains under strainagain</h2>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly:</strong> <a href="/featured-insights/themes/as-digital-opportunities-grow-digital-resilience-is-a-must">Supply chain resiliency</a> had already come to the fore as an urgent priority during COVID-19 lockdowns. And obviously, COVID-19 continues to be a dynamic issue, as were seeing right now in China and some parts of Europe. How much worse could this get?	</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>First, we need to reframe a bit what happened last year. The narrative was a broken supply chainbut the reality was an unbelievably strong supply chain. We had unprecedented levels of <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/risk-and-resilience-in-consumer-goods-supply-chains">demand for consumer-goods purchases</a> in the back half of 2021. And the supply chain actually delivered. The shelves were empty because everybody bought so much. A jittery supply chain could not have fulfilled this exceptionally high level of demand.</p>
<p>And why was there this demand? People were not buying services. They were not yet going on holiday, not going to the restaurantswhich caused an enormous demand shift toward goods. Now, at least in the West, you can see a rotation back to travel and to restaurants and other activities that may ease the demand on products a little and also relieve some pressure on the supply chain.</p>
<p>But of course, if <a href="/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/the-raw-materials-challenge-how-the-metals-and-mining-sector-will-be-at-the-core-of-enabling-the-energy-transition">basic materials</a> from Russia and Ukrainefood, metals, fertilizerare not shipped, then thats a problem. And some industries have important factories or important IT talent in Ukraine. If they cant access them, their supply chains could be impeded again. </p>
<p>Every single company I work with is now asking, What were we actually producing in Ukraine? Where did we get our nickel? Where did we get our cobalt? And then trying to figure out what to do.</p>
<h2>Economic implications in the eurozone and beyond</h2>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>Acknowledging that the context is incredibly dynamic, lets turn now to some of the ways this war might play out in the eurozone specifically, which is a very sizable macroeconomy and also very highly exposed. If hostilities were to be resolved diplomatically in the coming weeks, and we were to assume a modest policy response, what might the <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/war-in-ukraine-lives-and-livelihoods-lost-and-disrupted">economic implications of this war</a> be?</p>
<!-- -->
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>We might hope for this to happen. If it did, for example, we at least would be unlikely to see a stop to the supply of energy and certain critical materials, which would help. And if a resolution were to happen quickly, the refugee situation might not be quite as big, and it would be a bit faster to rebuild some of Ukraine. In that case, maybe the first or second quarter of this year might look wobbly, and then we might emerge back to some form of normal trajectory. But of course, it could get worse if the hostilities are more protracted, the sanctions stay longer at much higher levels, and so on. Then we could easily be two, three years under. </p>
<p>We dont, at this moment, expect the dip to be larger than the dip during the pandemic. The simple way to think about this is that COVID-19 created an enormous demand shock. That applied across all countries because we had lockdowns everywhere. Basically, because of this demand shock, aggregate demand fell. </p>
<p>Energy and food and the supply chainthese are very important. But even twice the price of energy is not a 10 percent GDP drop. Thats just how this translates. Im not saying theres no scenario imaginable where hostilities expand and you actually get a shutdown of the energy supply, in which case it could get much worse. But thats not the scenario were talking about right now.</p>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>Say a bit more about what might happen if the war drags on.</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>In that case, we would be a few years under with a few percent, and the question is, How do we restore together? Once a form of normality returns, you get a return to past growth. That depends a little bit on the energy mix. In a severe case, some stimulus to help the weakest get through will be important.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Once a form of normality returns, you get a return to past growth. That depends a little bit on the energy mix. In a severe case, some stimulus to help the weakest get through will be important.</p></blockquote></div>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly:</strong> Many economists expected 2022 to be the year the global economy bounced back after the shock of COVID-19. At the start of the year, we heard a lot of optimism about returning to prepandemic growth trajectories. All that very quickly changed following the invasion of Ukraine, and the economic outlook began to feel much more precarious. What can leaders expect globally, beyond the eurozone?</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>The eurozone is far more directly affected. It has the highest dependency on Russian energy and some of the other supply chains. We expect the US to do better and China, probably even better, although China is still dealing with another wave of COVID-19, which could be a factor. But if you just look at the war in Ukraine, Europe will feel it the most, then the US, and then China.</p>
<h2>Leading with lessons from COVID-19</h2>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly:</strong> Acknowledging variation among the leaders and organizations you work with, is there anything you think leaders can do right now to navigate the current uncertainty?	</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>Ive spoken to maybe 100 leaders by now. Basically, theyre going back to the playbook of dealing with COVID-19, by setting up some form of a <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/using-a-crisis-nerve-center-to-help-reopen-the-economy">crisis team</a>. And they all are, first, caring for their people, which they did during the pandemic, too. But in this situation, theyre asking, Where are my people? Where are they in Russia? What can we do? Where are they in Ukraine? What can we do about that? Who else is affected more indirectly? And then, in their crisis teams, theyre looking into, Can we continue our operations given our dependency on Ukraines supplies and on Russian supplies?</p>
<!-- -->
<p>The next level is, OK, how is this energy disruption going to hit me? These prices mean my products will be more expensive. What do I do? Does this mean people will have to spend more on energyand therefore that theyre likely to spend less on
my products?</p>
<p>Leaders are translating the information coming in to model supply disruption for their companies. And theyre asking what it will do to demand, as well. As they start adjusting their strategies, I think they are also likely to start <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-use-and-abuse-of-scenarios">scenario planning</a>. Theyre asking, What kind of storm are we weathering here and in what range?</p>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>Sven, Ive heard you say that the COVID-19 crisis actually helped revitalize the social contract by massively reinforcing the social safety net in places like Europe and the US, at least temporarily. How do you see the social contract evolving in the face of the war in Ukraine?</p>
<p><strong>Sven Smit: </strong>During COVID-19, the level of support to those affected by the pandemic has been enormous. Of course, you can always debate specific pointsfor example, Did it exactly land in the right place? But we did help restaurant owners. We did help factory workers. We did help people who couldnt work inside other peoples houses. </p>
<p>One way or the other, a significant amount of money landed in many places. This was the largest support action in a long, long time. We have increased debt-to-GDP ratios now, but in hindsight, people thought this was worth it. The alternative would have been much worsemass unemployment, no support. So I think we have a lesson here.</p>
<p>And even at the beginning of this year, when we were cutting the supply of oil and gas for other reasons, prices went up. Italy and Spain talk about billions in energy supportor they decouple VAT [value-added] taxes for energy to slightly compensate for the blow of the energy pricehoping that it wont sustain that long.</p>
<p>I also think we need to be careful not to be too light on how much these price increases can affect people. Some people say, This is the energy crisis; we anyway wanted people to shift to alternatives. And this is exactly the right thing to help fight the battle. That might be very easy to say if you have the money. But with the old prices, if food was 30 percent of your costs, thats now 90 percent. And that means theres nothing left. </p>
<p>Thats the pain that people feel. But as the pinch gets felt more directly, were already creating the kind of situation weve had during the pandemic. And clearly, were taking action because we recognize that this level of energy crisis and of food insecurityits not a good way for people to live.</p>
<p><strong>Lucia Rahilly: </strong>Thats very helpful, Sven. Thanks so much for joining us today.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/sven-smit">Sven Smit</a></strong> is a senior partner and chair of McKinsey Global Institute in McKinseys Amsterdam office. <strong>Lucia Rahilly</strong> is global editorial director and deputy publisher of McKinsey Global Publishing and is based in the New York office.</p>

Ukraine","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"97708cf4-8e15-42c4-bfb1-a849568cb6f7","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The rising toll of the war in Ukraine"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"The effects of the war in Ukraine"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Lives lost and upended. Soaring food and energy prices. Supply chains at risk. Much is at stake as the war continues."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"In this podcast, senior partner and chair of the McKinsey Global Institute, Sven Smit, discusses the rising toll and ongoing effects of the war in Ukraine. "},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-03-30T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn this episode\u003c/strong\u003e of \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, Sven Smit, senior partner and chair of the McKinsey Global Institute, talks with Lucia Rahilly, global editorial director, about some of the potential effects of ongoing war and uncertainty in Ukraine. This conversation was recorded on March 21, 2022. An edited transcript follows.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe McKinsey Podcast\u003c/em\u003e is cohosted by Roberta Fusaro and Lucia Rahilly.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[audio 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eA human\u0026mdash;and humanitarian\u0026mdash;crisis \u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly:\u003c/strong\u003e I recognize this is a chaotic time for you, given the brutal effects of the war in Ukraine and ongoing shock and uncertainty, both in the European region and worldwide. We\u0026rsquo;re very grateful you were able to make the time to talk with us today.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit:\u003c/strong\u003e It\u0026rsquo;s indeed a complex time. I live in Europe, and this is so close that you can\u0026rsquo;t get it out of your heart. My mother is 80. She lived in Eastern Germany and fled from government oppression in the \u0026rsquo;60s. She didn\u0026rsquo;t think she would live to see this again. And now it\u0026rsquo;s happening on our territory while we\u0026rsquo;re watching. This is a true atrocity and a humanitarian pain that\u0026rsquo;s unimaginable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eThe war clearly affects all of us, but it must be particularly acutely felt in Europe, even outside the conflict zone. It\u0026rsquo;s the largest war in Europe in nearly eight decades. So I would imagine you\u0026rsquo;re hearing similar things from the leaders you talk to day-to-day.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit:\u003c/strong\u003e Yes. The pandemic is a virus. We can fight it with masks and vaccines. But in Ukraine, we\u0026rsquo;re fighting human against human\u0026mdash;and that\u0026rsquo;s just so different.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1Up globalpodcast]]\n\u003ch2\u003eLives and livelihoods, lost and disrupted\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eThis war is obviously causing massive disruption on a range of fronts. We can\u0026rsquo;t talk today about all of them, but let\u0026rsquo;s touch on at least a few. The foremost disruption, as you alluded to, is the horrific and rising toll on lives. What have we learned so far about the scale of this humanitarian tragedy\u0026mdash;and about who is likely to bear the brunt of much of this suffering?\t\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eAt the moment, north of a few million people are moving out of Ukraine as refugees. That number could grow much bigger if the hostilities protract for the remainder of the year. Some people estimate it might then go north of ten million, 15 million. But there are different segments\u0026mdash;the lives lost in the direct war, the displacement of refugees, and the displacement within Ukraine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe energy and food crises are also pinching at the lives and livelihoods of people across the world. Among some less-well-off populations in Western Europe or the United States, energy and food make up 10\u0026ndash;30 percent of what they spend. The price doubles, triples\u0026mdash;all of a sudden, these people can\u0026rsquo;t do anything else but pay for food and energy. So you see some people already adjusting their behavior, eating less. And some of them just can\u0026rsquo;t pay.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen you multiply that in a low-income country\u0026mdash;one that maybe had an aspiring population, ready to go up the next step. Now these people get pinched by this increased price of food, increased price of energy, maybe even decreased access to food and energy. And you can easily imagine that more lives and livelihoods will be lost and disrupted outside the immediate conflict. We should not miss that. In the pandemic, there was a little bit of an under-told story: richer countries were really not paying enough attention to the pain of this economic disruption in lower-income countries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eRising prices, rising risk\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eFood prices spiked even prior to the war, given supply chain issues and rising energy prices during the pandemic. In the US, we saw grocery prices shoot up at the highest rate in something like 40 years. Do you see increased food insecurity in Europe\u0026mdash;and potentially also an increase in world hunger\u0026mdash;as a big risk as a result of this war?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eWe haven\u0026rsquo;t yet seen shipments of oil, gas, and food stopping at a massive scale. There hasn\u0026rsquo;t been a major harvest disrupted in the northern territory, which could happen if this goes through the summer. We also haven\u0026rsquo;t yet seen some form of sanction or countersanction or hostility saying, \u0026ldquo;Let\u0026rsquo;s not ship the oil.\u0026rdquo; But if that changes, either by physical disruption or by intent, we may see problems with access.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eAt the moment, prices are rising in anticipation of potential shortages. And what will happen is high-income countries will buy\u0026mdash;they\u0026rsquo;ll be able to pay. And lower-income countries will have access problems\u0026mdash;or at minimum, even greater affordability problems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eIn some lower-income countries, there is also a history of food shortages and rising food costs contributing to social unrest and uprising. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eThat\u0026rsquo;s not just a risk in low-income countries. The yellow-vest movement reacted to an increase in diesel prices. Only a small increase in these items\u0026mdash;which you need to buy to stay warm, to drive to your job, to earn an income\u0026mdash;is very disruptive. It means you have to stop buying other stuff. And that\u0026rsquo;s where the pain comes. Of course, for some, that means not going on holiday\u0026mdash;not the worst thing in life. But for others, it means cutting back on essentials because their spend gets crowded out by these enormous price rises.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe\u0026rsquo;re all experiencing just how sensitive a doubling of the price in oil or doubling in the price of food is to the spending patterns of the lower-income parts of the population. It\u0026rsquo;s very easy for higher-income people to say, \u0026ldquo;You know, this is part of the fight,\u0026rdquo; but it really pinches other segments of the population.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat about net zero?\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Video 4]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eEnergy is obviously a huge disruption, given the role of Russian oil and gas not just in Europe but worldwide. I saw a quote a couple of days ago from the International Energy Agency warning that we could be headed into what they called the biggest supply crisis in decades. Sven, you\u0026rsquo;ve been so heavily involved in our energy research, including our recent report on the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-net-zero-transition-what-it-would-cost-what-it-could-bring\"\u003enet-zero transition\u003c/a\u003e. Anything more to say about energy access, at least in the near to medium term?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eThe first point is the energy is still flowing. But it could stop flowing. So we need to do much more radical things. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCurrently, the energy policy of major countries is rotating: \u0026ldquo;Let\u0026rsquo;s build more wind. Let\u0026rsquo;s build more solar. Let\u0026rsquo;s build more nuclear.\u0026rdquo; It\u0026rsquo;s almost like saying, \u0026ldquo;Let\u0026rsquo;s try everything and find out what protects us the fastest.\u0026rdquo; What that does to net zero, what that does to the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/solving-the-net-zero-equation-nine-requirements-for-a-more-orderly-transition\"\u003enet-zero equation\u003c/a\u003e, I think we will only learn over time. Because the reality is that some countries might start reoperating coal plants as the fastest way to become somewhat less dependent. And other countries might actually \u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/capturing-the-wind-renewable-energy-opportunities-in-vietnam\"\u003efinalize the wind farms\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that are already there.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor now, people are going to go all out. And then, at some point, we will resettle into a new equilibrium, which could go either way. For physical supply chains of energy that are now at stake, oil travels a little bit more on boats and can therefore be flexibly reallocated, while gas needs to be liquefied and then re-gassed. And the capacity for liquefication (SIC) and re-gassing is actually short. As a result, if we were to have a gas shortage, rebuilding might take a lot of time\u0026mdash;much more time than we ever want.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSupply chains under strain\u0026mdash;again\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Video 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly:\u003c/strong\u003e \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/themes/as-digital-opportunities-grow-digital-resilience-is-a-must\"\u003eSupply chain resiliency\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;had already come to the fore as an urgent priority during COVID-19 lockdowns. And obviously, COVID-19 continues to be a dynamic issue, as we\u0026rsquo;re seeing right now in China and some parts of Europe. How much worse could this get?\t\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eFirst, we need to reframe a bit what happened last year. The narrative was a broken supply chain\u0026mdash;but the reality was an unbelievably strong supply chain. We had unprecedented levels of \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/risk-and-resilience-in-consumer-goods-supply-chains\"\u003edemand for consumer-goods purchases\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the back half of 2021. And the supply chain actually delivered. The shelves were empty because everybody bought so much. A jittery supply chain could not have fulfilled this exceptionally high level of demand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd why was there this demand? People were not buying services. They were not yet going on holiday, not going to the restaurants\u0026mdash;which caused an enormous demand shift toward goods. Now, at least in the West, you can see a rotation back to travel and to restaurants and other activities that may ease the demand on products a little and also relieve some pressure on the supply chain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut of course, if \u003ca href=\"/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/the-raw-materials-challenge-how-the-metals-and-mining-sector-will-be-at-the-core-of-enabling-the-energy-transition\"\u003ebasic materials\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;from Russia and Ukraine\u0026mdash;food, metals, fertilizer\u0026mdash;are not shipped, then that\u0026rsquo;s a problem. And some industries have important factories or important IT talent in Ukraine. If they can\u0026rsquo;t access them, their supply chains could be impeded again. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEvery single company I work with is now asking, \u0026ldquo;What were we actually producing in Ukraine? Where did we get our nickel? Where did we get our cobalt?\u0026rdquo; And then trying to figure out what to do.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eEconomic implications in the eurozone and beyond\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eAcknowledging that the context is incredibly dynamic, let\u0026rsquo;s turn now to some of the ways this war might play out in the eurozone specifically, which is a very sizable macroeconomy and also very highly exposed. If hostilities were to be resolved diplomatically in the coming weeks, and we were to assume a modest policy response, what might the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/war-in-ukraine-lives-and-livelihoods-lost-and-disrupted\"\u003eeconomic implications of this war\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;be?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 3]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eWe might hope for this to happen. If it did, for example, we at least would be unlikely to see a stop to the supply of energy and certain critical materials, which would help. And if a resolution were to happen quickly, the refugee situation might not be quite as big, and it would be a bit faster to rebuild some of Ukraine. In that case, maybe the first or second quarter of this year might look wobbly, and then we might emerge back to some form of normal trajectory. But of course, it could get worse if the hostilities are more protracted, the sanctions stay longer at much higher levels, and so on. Then we could easily be two, three years under. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe don\u0026rsquo;t, at this moment, expect the dip to be larger than the dip during the pandemic. The simple way to think about this is that COVID-19 created an enormous demand shock. That applied across all countries because we had lockdowns everywhere. Basically, because of this demand shock, aggregate demand fell. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEnergy and food and the supply chain\u0026mdash;these are very important. But even twice the price of energy is not a 10 percent GDP drop. That\u0026rsquo;s just how this translates. I\u0026rsquo;m not saying there\u0026rsquo;s no scenario imaginable where hostilities expand and you actually get a shutdown of the energy supply, in which case it could get much worse. But that\u0026rsquo;s not the scenario we\u0026rsquo;re talking about right now.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eSay a bit more about what might happen if the war drags on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eIn that case, we would be a few years under with a few percent, and the question is, \u0026ldquo;How do we restore together?\u0026rdquo; Once a form of normality returns, you get a return to past growth. That depends a little bit on the energy mix. In a severe case, some stimulus to help the weakest get through will be important.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly:\u003c/strong\u003e Many economists expected 2022 to be the year the global economy bounced back after the shock of COVID-19. At the start of the year, we heard a lot of optimism about returning to prepandemic growth trajectories. All that very quickly changed following the invasion of Ukraine, and the economic outlook began to feel much more precarious. What can leaders expect globally, beyond the eurozone?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eThe eurozone is far more directly affected. It has the highest dependency on Russian energy and some of the other supply chains. We expect the US to do better and China, probably even better, although China is still dealing with another wave of COVID-19, which could be a factor. But if you just look at the war in Ukraine, Europe will feel it the most, then the US, and then China.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eLeading with lessons from COVID-19\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly:\u003c/strong\u003e Acknowledging variation among the leaders and organizations you work with, is there anything you think leaders can do right now to navigate the current uncertainty?\t\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eI\u0026rsquo;ve spoken to maybe 100 leaders by now. Basically, they\u0026rsquo;re going back to the playbook of dealing with COVID-19, by setting up some form of a \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/using-a-crisis-nerve-center-to-help-reopen-the-economy\"\u003ecrisis team\u003c/a\u003e. And they all are, first, caring for their people, which they did during the pandemic, too. But in this situation, they\u0026rsquo;re asking, \u0026ldquo;Where are my people? Where are they in Russia? What can we do? Where are they in Ukraine? What can we do about that? Who else is affected more indirectly?\u0026rdquo; And then, in their crisis teams, they\u0026rsquo;re looking into, \u0026ldquo;Can we continue our operations given our dependency on Ukraine\u0026rsquo;s supplies and on Russian supplies?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Video 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe next level is, \u0026ldquo;OK, how is this energy disruption going to hit me? These prices mean my products will be more expensive. What do I do? Does this mean people will have to spend more on energy\u0026mdash;and therefore that they\u0026rsquo;re likely to spend less on\nmy products?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLeaders are translating the information coming in to model supply disruption for their companies. And they\u0026rsquo;re asking what it will do to demand, as well. As they start adjusting their strategies, I think they are also likely to start \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-use-and-abuse-of-scenarios\"\u003escenario planning\u003c/a\u003e. They\u0026rsquo;re asking, \u0026ldquo;What kind of storm are we weathering here and in what range?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eSven, I\u0026rsquo;ve heard you say that the COVID-19 crisis actually helped revitalize the social contract by massively reinforcing the social safety net in places like Europe and the US, at least temporarily. How do you see the social contract evolving in the face of the war in Ukraine?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSven Smit: \u003c/strong\u003eDuring COVID-19, the level of support to those affected by the pandemic has been enormous. Of course, you can always debate specific points\u0026mdash;for example, \u0026ldquo;Did it exactly land in the right place?\u0026rdquo; But we did help restaurant owners. We did help factory workers. We did help people who couldn\u0026rsquo;t work inside other people\u0026rsquo;s houses. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne way or the other, a significant amount of money landed in many places. This was the largest support action in a long, long time. We have increased debt-to-GDP ratios now, but in hindsight, people thought this was worth it. The alternative would have been much worse\u0026mdash;mass unemployment, no support. So I think we have a lesson here.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnd even at the beginning of this year, when we were cutting the supply of oil and gas for other reasons, prices went up. Italy and Spain talk about billions in energy support\u0026mdash;or they decouple VAT [value-added] taxes for energy to slightly compensate for the blow of the energy price\u0026mdash;hoping that it won\u0026rsquo;t sustain that long.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI also think we need to be careful not to be too light on how much these price increases can affect people. Some people say, \u0026ldquo;This is the energy crisis; we anyway wanted people to shift to alternatives. And this is exactly the right thing to help fight the battle.\u0026rdquo; That might be very easy to say if you have the money. But with the old prices, if food was 30 percent of your costs, that\u0026rsquo;s now 90 percent. And that means there\u0026rsquo;s nothing left. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat\u0026rsquo;s the pain that people feel. But as the pinch gets felt more directly, we\u0026rsquo;re already creating the kind of situation we\u0026rsquo;ve had during the pandemic. And clearly, we\u0026rsquo;re taking action because we recognize that this level of energy crisis and of food insecurity\u0026mdash;it\u0026rsquo;s not a good way for people to live.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLucia Rahilly: \u003c/strong\u003eThat\u0026rsquo;s very helpful, Sven.
